content.content: ### Complications which can cause death:[^52][^84][^94][^103][^106] - Infection - Sepsis - Falls - Blood clot - Drug errors ### Signs of a Rapidly Declining Patient[^7][^10][^24][^85][^95][^150][^151][^152][^153][^154][^155][^156][^157][^158] - Shortness of breath, gasping, panting and/or fast breathing - Very slow breathing - Drop in blood pressure - Becomes very pale - Cold sweats, fever or chills - Confusion, dizziness, &/or acting strangely - Increase or decrease in heart rate - Extreme pain - Swelling of the face and hands - Low urine output - Seeing spots, flashing lights, blurring or unable to see - Bleeding from gums, nose, eyes or in urine &/or bowel movements - Seizures  - High or low temperature - Changes in heart rate - Patient doesn’t look right ### Prevention of Complications:[^150][^151][^152][^153][^154][^155][^156][^157][^158] - Recognizing abnormal vital signs - Recognizing abnormal lab results - Early warning system of monitors (pulse oximetry, heart rate, blood pressure & capnometry) - Rapid response to patient’s declining condition - Rapid & open communication and "huddles" between medical staff - Rapid treatment of complication - Family participation in nurse and doctor bedside reports - Nurses & families alerting Rapid Response Team - Patient and family engagement __Use the Hospital Plan of Care form to advocate and ask questions about your loved one.__ [The Hospital Plan of Care form](https://patientsafetymovement.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/POC-Blank-April-19.pdf "The Hospital Plan of Care form") [Guide to Medical Care at a Distance](https://patientsafetymovement.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Guide-to-Medical-Care-at-a-Distance.pdf "Guide to Medical Care at a Distance") ### Reasons Why Patients Could Fail:[^150][^151][^152][^153][^154][^155][^156][^157][^158] - Poor communication between healthcare providers - Understaffing - Outdated communication technologies - Hierarchical barriers between medical staff - Not recognizing a deteriorating patient - Incomplete handoffs between healthcare providers - Not responding rapidly to an impending or ongoing crisis - Medical staff not engaging with patients and families Embedded content: https://youtu.be/ssWSoN00yxI?list=PL1t1eQbvK0Qfazr_n1QINPGayr1A5eghE ### If Something Goes Wrong: 1\. Speak with someone right away. If you believe you have experienced a medical error or if you would like to report a high-risk situation, please contact the hospital's ombudsman, or the designated person responsible for discussing and investigating complaints and reports, before contacting CMS or the public health governing body.[^160] 2\. Ask respectfully for an honest and clear explanation from the healthcare provider.[^160][^161] 3\. Ask for an investigation into the mistake and a family meeting to explain the results.[^160][^161] 4\. Ask for the Patient Advocacy, the Patient & Family Relations and/or the Risk Management department for help.[^160][^161] 5\. If needed after the discussion with the ombudsman, contact your state's public health services. [Find your State's Health Department](https://www.usa.gov/state-health)[^162] For Medicare patients contact Medicare at 1-800-MEDICARE or [How to file a complaint (grievance) on Medicare website](https://www.medicare.gov/claims-and-appeals/file-a-complaint/complaint.html)[^162] 6\. Contact the Joint Commission at 1-800-994-6610 or [The Joint Commission's Report a Patient Safety Event](https://www.jointcommission.org/report_a_complaint.aspx)[^162] 7\. Doctors and nurses are ethically bound to disclose medical errors.[^163][^164] [Patient Safety Voices Advice from ProPublica](https://www.propublica.org/article/patient-safety-voices-advice) [^7]: Hallisey J.
